benchmark_config.jira_title: Implement/Test API: PUT /1.0/kb/accounts/{accountId}/cbaRebalancing - Rebalance account CBA

covered: Valid PUT requests and success responses: TC01–TC07 and TC19 verify HTTP 204 and backend CBA recalculation across many account states (zero, positive, negative, large, multiple transactions, regression state).

Required and optional header validation: TC01–TC03 verify X-Killbill-CreatedBy presence and TC02 verifies optional X-Killbill-Reason and X-Killbill-Comment. Negative header cases are covered by TC10, TC11, TC25 and TC26 (missing/empty/whitespace/null).

Path parameter validation & non-existent resources: TC08, TC09, TC16 and TC17 exercise invalid UUID formats, oversized accountId values, non-existing accounts and empty DB, asserting 400 for invalid account IDs.
Error and edge-case handling: TC12 (extra unsupported headers) and TC23 (unexpected query params) verify tolerant behavior; TC22 checks unsupported HTTP method -> 405.
Resilience/availability & retry: TC13 verifies retry behavior on transient network errors; TC14 covers service unavailable (503).
Security tests: TC15 (SQL injection payload in header) and TC24 (XSS in comment) exercise input sanitization and non-leakage of implementation details.
Concurrency & performance: TC18 (high concurrency), TC20 (response within 2s normal load) and TC21 (peak load within 5s) cover concurrency and basic performance goals.
Boundary and numeric-state scenarios: TC04, TC05, TC06 cover zero, negative and very large positive CBA states; TC07 covers multiple CBA-impacting transactions.
Backend state verification: Many scenarios explicitly assert that CBA is rebalanced in the backend (not only status codes).
Specification conformance for success & common errors: Success (204) and common client errors for invalid account id (400) are covered by multiple test cases.
gaps: Authorization / authentication negative tests: No scenarios cover missing/invalid auth token or insufficient permissions (401/403). The Background assumes a valid token but negative auth tests are absent.
Response headers & content validation: No checks for Content-Type (application/json per spec), verification that 204 responses contain no body, or that error responses follow a JSON schema.
Idempotency: No explicit test that repeated/sequential PUT calls are idempotent (state stability across repeated calls).
Handling of unexpected request body: Spec says Request Body: N/A but there is no test for behavior when a non-empty body is sent (ignored vs rejected).
Server-side 5xx and transactional atomicity: Only 503 is tested; 500 Internal Server Error scenarios, partial failures and rollback/atomicity are not covered.
Header size and encoding limits: No tests for very long CreatedBy/Reason/Comment values, nor for unicode/non-ASCII header handling.
Numeric precision/overflow for CBA: No tests verify fractional currency precision, rounding rules, or overflow when rebalancing extreme balances.
Audit/logging of headers: No verification that CreatedBy/Reason/Comment are recorded in audit/event logs tied to the rebalancing operation.
Rate limiting/throttling: No tests for server-side throttling (429) or behavior under extreme request bursts beyond performance timing checks.

Negative concurrency/failure modes: Concurrency tests check success under load but do not exercise race conditions that cause locks/conflicts or verify conflict responses (e.g., 409) or retry backoff semantics.
recommendations: Add authentication/authorization negative tests: missing token -> expect 401; invalid token or insufficient privileges -> expect 401/403.
Assert response headers and body behavior: verify Content-Type on error responses, assert 204 responses have appropriate no-content behavior (no body) and any required headers (e.g., Allow on 405).
Add idempotency tests: run the same PUT twice (sequentially) and assert the second call is safe (204) and there is no double application of changes.
Test handling of non-empty request body: send various payloads with PUT and assert documented behavior (ignored vs validation error) is enforced.
Simulate server 500 and test transactional rollback: induce DB/service failure mid-operation and assert no partial updates persist (or document expected behavior).
Add header length and encoding tests: very long CreatedBy/Reason/Comment values and non-ASCII/unicode content to validate limits and encoding handling.
Add numeric precision and overflow scenarios: fractional-cent balances, very large balances and rounding tests to ensure correct monetary behavior.
Verify audit/logging: check that CreatedBy, Reason and Comment are recorded in rebalancing events or audit trail with the correct values.
Include rate-limiting/throttling tests: burst requests to validate 429 responses and graceful degradation or backoff behavior.
Extend concurrency tests to negative/failure cases: craft race conditions that provoke lock conflicts/timeouts and verify deterministic, documented outcomes (retry, 409, or serialized updates).
